description: 1967 FORD MUSTANG C CODE CONVERTIBLE. OVER 30K SPENT ON RESTORATION AND NEEDS MINOR FINISHING. REBUILT 289, UP GRADED TO 4 BBL. AUTO, POWER FRONT DISC BRAKE KIT. POWER STEERING, POWER TOP. FACTORY A/C . SOLID BODY AND FLOORS . LONGTIME TEXAS CAR. NEW INTERIOR NEEDS FINISHING. NEW PAINT- SOME CHIPS AND SCRATCHES AND DINGS. NEW CHROME. NEW POWER TOP . SMALL TEAR IN  OUTER LAYER. RUNS , AND STOP. THERE IS A FUEL ISSUE WHERE THE CAR RUNS THEN STOPS RUNNING. TEXAS TITLE
A cool personality, the right features, and an affordable price – this 1965 Ford Mustang understands how to make an appealing V8 total package.

A Mustang with a recent professional respray of its factory-correct Silver Smoke Grey is already distinctive.  But what makes this one stand apart even further is an intricate set of pinstripes on the hood, around the doors, on the c-pillar, atop the trunk, and surrounding the pony gas cap.  And we especially like the subtle one that highlights the full c-channel crease in the sheetmetal's profile.  And all the details are nice, too, like the complete brightwork, newer halogen headlights, and classic slotted alloy wheels.  The result is an iconic coupe with enough custom touches that will make people think you spent plenty more.

A black interior always looks great against the silver, and in this case, it's even better because all the black in the pinstriping on the exterior really make this look like a terrifically coordinated package inside & out.  But more than just the right color combo, you'll love this one because they made the right investments.  For example, the bucket seat covers and carpeting are newer to give this classic a fresh feeling.  You get the vintage Mustang three-spoke sports steering wheel.  That gives you a clear view to the wide speedometer flanked by readouts for all the important info.  Plus, that bright Hurst shifter is just calling out for your right hand in all the darkness.

This C-code Mustang has a correct 289 V8 under the hood, but you can instantly see this has been upgraded for show and go.  Polished valve covers and a matching air topper radiate nicely against the glossy black engine bay.  Plus, this V8 has been given performance upgrades such as a Holley four-barrel carburetor, Edelbrock intake, Mallory coil/distributor, and a nice set of headers that feed the stainless dual exhaust.  And you have complete control over this enhanced V8 and its rumbling soundtrack thanks to the three-speed manual transmission.

The sale comes with good paperwork, including the original dealer invoice and owner's manual.  So when a distinct and powerful pony like this is also quite affordable, you know you need to hurry to grab this deal.  Call today!!!

This 1966 Ford Mustang Convertible is now available for sale at our Gateway Classic Cars Showroom in Saint Louis. This straight-six jewel is just about as close are you find these days to the original production.The interior and exterior are in great condition. There is no deteriorating rust anywhere on the vehicle and the body is great shape; lacking any noticeable scratches dents or dings. The yellow watermelon satin finish on the exterior doesnt need any work done to it.  It shines as good as a recently done paint job. The powered convertible top closes nice and tight and does not have any discoloration or damage. The interior is also in wonderful condition with barely any hint of wear on the seats; the front dash also doesnt have any tears or fading; the carpeting is clean and glued tight to the flood.The powerplant for this 1966 Ford Mustang Convertible is a 200Ci Straight Inline Six-Cylinder that runs strong and is ready to do what you need it to do one day one. The automatic transmission shifts perfectly; allowing you the opportunity to enjoy your top-down cruise whenever the temperature is above warm-enough.To view this 1966 Ford Mustang Convertible in greater detail including HD pictures and an HD video visit www.GatewayClassicCars.com or our St. Louis Showroom. Adding to the red of this car is red vinyl and carpet in the interior and under the hood is where your friend will start seeing red as nestled in the narrow valley between the shock towers is a Ford 390 Cubic inch FE Big block power plant! Now I could have used the term "??engine"? or maybe "??Mill"? perhaps but Power plant works best with 390 FE Ford. Sitting on top of this torque monster is a Holley ® 4 barrel Carburetor to keep the energy fed to the thirst FE and giving you the instant throttle response that we all love.  Backing this combo is the hardy C6 3 speed automatic transmission to give you tire shredding launches and still keep the rpms low on the interstate.  This S code 1967 Mustang for sale was well equipped with it left the factory 51 Years ago some of the options that stand out are Air conditioning and power steering! This classic pony car was one of the first to usher in the small car big engine idea that helped a lot of us fall in love with cars. This little "??67 Mustang for sale has one more added bonus the owner states that it has an incredible low 56786 miles on it! If I had purchased this car in 1967 I would have added that number to the odometer before heading home with the car. If you have always wanted one of these original sleepers now is your chance do not pass it by as "??S"? Code 1967"??s don"??t pop up for sale everyday.Options for this 1967 Mustang for sale include: Air Condition ( currently not blowing cold ) AM/FM Cd player Power steering Vinyl interior and American Racing ® 5 spoke rims. Gateway Classic Cars is proud to present this quintessential example of a 1967 Ford Mustang Coupe! The Ford Mustang was introduced unto the world on April 17th 1964. The Mustang conceptualized from the already popular Ford Falcon provided the American working-class with a chance to own a modest sports car with a modest price tag all without sacrificing overall enjoyment or amenities.Shortly after beginning production in mid-1964 the Mustang underwent extreme body modifications every couple of years the first small tweak is seen here with this 1967. The 1967 and 1968 models were elongated by a few inches with modifications to the car taking place in the front nose as well as the sharpening of the body lines along the sides while the rear taillight panel would now present itself with an indention rather than a protrusion. Smaller underpowered 8 cylinder motors were now offered with larger displacement than the first two production years as well as more horsepower and more amenities (such as back up lights).Upon decoding the VIN and datacode plate we find that this particular C-Code 1967 (original 289cid v8 2bbl) was birthed in the San Jose plant before being shipped to Seattle for sale. An additional comfort that we find in this decoding of the Mustang is that this 1967 was Candy Apple Red from the factory as well as adorned with black buckets making her trim-code matching and very period-correct.For more information and to view dozens of HD pictures and a video of it running and driving please visit www.GATEWAYCLASSICCARS.com and dial (708) 444-4488.See more at: http://www.gatewayclassiccars.com/CHI/1459/1967-Ford-Mustang

Engine...200 CID L6...original block, head, rebuilt late 1990's, bored 0.030” over, hardened valve seats, DUI electronic ignition (2017), new plugs & wires (2017), 2 barrel Weber carb (2017), dual outlet powder coated full length headers (2014), 3-row V8 radiator, 60 amp V8 alternator...aftermarket fuel pump, starter, battery is 2 yrs old Body...replaced front fenders and hood, cheater rear quarters rolled in lead, replaced both front and rear valences, new bumpers front and rear, all trim replaced. Painted in late 1990's in “Porsche red” (original factory color is Raven Black); Interior...all replaced with new - seat covers & foam, carpet, door panels, doors and quarter covers all refurbished, new hardware including window cranks, and Grant steering wheel - interior kept original “parchment” color; custom 8 speaker, 3 amplifier sound system w/ 6 CD changer mounted in glove compartment; custom finished trunk in black carpet Chassis...stiffened rear leaf springs over normal 6 Cyl car - all new bushings, shocks, and hardware; front suspension completely replaced with new; power steering pump, hoses, piston all new (2 yrs old); front disc brake conversion (2013) with new dual master cylinder and proportioning valve; rear brakes replaced (2016) with new shoes and wheel cylinders; replaced fuel tank; American Racing 4 lug wheels; rear end seals replaced (2017); trans recently serviced (2017); true dual exhaust with stainless steel “Arvinode” resonator system (2015) cost more than $1000 - added V8/GT rear floor pan plates for dual exhaust hangers; all floor pans replaced Very nice driver car. Have all receipts with well over $35K into it.

Just as they were more than 50 years ago, Mustangs are fast, fun, and affordable ways to get around. Traditional ponies like this 1965 Ford Mustang coupe are a great way to own an icon without spending a ton of money, and when they carry a few clever updates, they make wonderful hobby vehicles that can still be enjoyed every day.

Seriously, if you could own a classic V8-powered Mustang coupe for less than the price of a new one with a 4-cylinder engine, why wouldn't you leap at the chance? Especially one with A/C, power steering, and disc brakes? Nicely refinished, this Wimbledon White coupe carries all the timeless design cues that put these cars at the top of every enthusiast's wish list. Bodywork is well done, it has a classic color combination, and everything lines up well enough to really attract positive attention at local shows. The line that runs along the tops of the fenders is as sharp as a crease in Don Draper's suit, and the paint is shiny without looking too modern. It's got the correct front grille with the ''crosshairs'' in the center emblem, optional chrome trim on the quarters, and it's nice that it hasn't been forced to wear stripes or wings like so many of its siblings. The chrome is in very shape, too, totally in line with the rest of the car, giving it a clean all-of-a-piece look.

Red upholstery makes the interior a brilliant place to spend some time. Restored with the rest of the car, the interior offers a lot of new components, including seat covers, door panels, dash pad, and carpets, all of which show very little use. Factory gauges all work properly and you'll note there's a custom center console with cup holders that is a modern addition that adds practicality. The original AM radio has been replaced by an AM/FM/cassette head unit and that's a recent A/C system tucked under the dash, not quite like it would have been in 1965 but still very slick. Power steering is a desirable option, even on the lightweight Mustang and the three-spoke steering wheel that controls it is in excellent shape as well. Even the trunk is correctly finished with a plaid mat and spare tire with matching cover.

Classic performance in a Mustang means only one thing: a snappy 289 cubic inch V8. This is a C-code car, so you get a relatively economic 2-barrel carburetor that still delivers plenty of V8 punch. And when your car runs this well, there's really no need for upgrades and modifications, instead letting the spirit of 1965 flow through you whenever you're behind the wheel. It fires easily and has a snarky V8 exhaust note thanks to a fresh dual exhaust system. Ford Blue on the engine makes it look right, and it's pretty much the way Ford intended, from the air cleaner to the big radiator, although the A/C compressor and power dual master cylinder are modern additions. The undercarriage is not shiny, but if you're into driving instead of polishing your car at static shows, you'll never even notice, and front disc brakes have been added. A C4 3-speed automatic transmission spins the original 8-inch rear with tall gears inside, so it's great on the highway. 14-inch styled steel wheels look great on any early Mustang, and they're protected by 195/75/14 Goodyear whitewall radials.
We seem to be getting lucky with early Mustangs here at Streetside Classics, but don't wait for the next one, you need to put this lovely '65 coupe in your garage right away! Call now!

We are pleased to present this Candy Apple Red 1966 Mustang C code convertible with an outstanding history file. This car was built in San Jose and stayed in California until 1994.  This all original car was purchased in the Los Angeles area in November 1968 and stayed in the family since then. The original Purchase Receipt from 1968 is included.   Everything is original except for the convertible top that was replaced in 1986, the padded dash and the AM/FM/CD player. All the gauges are original and are operational including the dealer installed Rally Pack except the clock does not work. The C4 3 speed automatic transmission shifts smoothly and 289 V8 with 2 bbl carburetor runs great. The engine still has the California air pump installed.  The power steering has a little play in it which is normal for a 50 plus year old car. The power top operates normally but there is a rip in the fabric above the back window.  The car was repainted eleven years ago and kept the original candy apple red color.  This vehicle has been driven as intended but also maintained as the substantial amount of receipts dating back to 1968 can prove. The original interior is in great shape with no rips or tears.  The back seat is faded but still holding up very well for its age with only some minor cracking on the back seat and wear in the piping on the drivers seat.  We can arrange shipping to your location. If you have any questions, please contact Savannah Classic Cars 912-235-2347.

2 owner, 83,600 mile car. Clean, rust free car. Very unmolested. Stored for 27 years! The woman that bought the car parked it in 1976. 2nd owner bought it and pulled it out of hibernation in 2013. He went on to service and restore the car to it's current condition.

EXTERIOR: Only repainted 1 time, exterior only. The jambs are still original, complete with old oil change stickers. Has original dealer's label on the back, it was carefully painted around. Body is excellent with no damage or rust. Bumpers, mirror, taillights, handles have bright chrome. This car does have the optional Sprint hood with the louvers and built in turn signals. The owner did recently add GT wheels to dress it up and a brand new set of tires.

INTERIOR: Mostly in very good original condition. The front seats have been reupholstered, door panels and armrests have been replaced. Has the original carpet, headliner and rear seat. The dash pad is very good. Has Pony floormats. New instrument bezels with bright chrome trim. The radio is a conversion, it looks stock but actually has modern guts. It is Bluetooth and FM stereo with speakers. New air conditioning system, the owner says it will drop ice cubes on your lap.

MOTOR COMPARTMENT: Very clean and proper. The 289 motor is painted Ford blue. Has correct manifolds and air cleaner complete with heat riser tube. Rebuilt carb, new fuel pump. Upgraded steel timing gear. Upgraded aluminum radiator keeps the motor cool. The air conditioning system is entirely new. Has washer bottle, Autolite battery topper, underside hood light- Has power steering and brakes.
UNDERSIDE: Completely rock solid, original floors and frame rails. Brakes were redone, gas tank, leaf springs and shocks replaced.
TRUNK COMPARTMENT: Clean original. Has mat, tire cover, jack and spare.
Good, honest Mustang with the winning combination- V-8, automatic, air conditioning, power steering and brakes!

1966 Ford Mustang Custom Coupe

In a world where mechanics and performance components are constantly evolving it only make since that Restomods have become one of the most popular vintage cars on the road today. The all original stock cars certainly have their place and are appreciated but unless you are just going to local shows they aren't very ideal. That is where the restomod comes in. These cars take a vintage look and upgrade it with more modern technology to make it much more road worthy in the current times. The cool 66 Mustang Coupe you see here is done in the Restomod style with a little hotrod flair to make it one cool custom. The body of the car is nice and straight with no problems. It is painted in a Silver metallic color with Black racing strips and the finish has a great shine. The top of the car was painted a gloss Black as well which creates a really cool look. It almost references the old vinyl top cars. A custom hood has been added that incorporates a cowl with two small scoops up front. This gives it a really neat appearance from the front especially because the hood fits with the racing stripes so well. An aftermarket custom grill has been added as well as the Shelby style front valance. The Weld Racing wheels under the car have a nice shine and look very tough.

The wider tires in the back let you know it has a little more packed under the hood than it did originally. It is now powered by a 347 Stroker motor that runs very strong. It has been built up with an aftermarket cam, AFR aluminum heads, MSD distributor, and Ford Racing valve covers. It has a great sound and the car runs down the road nicely. The motor is paired with a C6 Automatic transmission that smoothly shifts power back to the Ford 9 inch rear end. Disc brakes have been added all around and are power assisted.

The interior is done in Black and is all custom. The upholstery work looks great and the inserts are done in a honeycomb pattern that looks really cool. The center console was custom built and incorporates cupholders, storage space and a ratchet style shifter. The original gauges have been redone with white overlays and a second underdash gauge bezel has been added for oil, amp, water as well as a tachometer with shift kit. An aftermarket stereo has also been installed and is a Pioneer AM/FM/CD/Bluetooth unit that sounds great. The trunk is painted Black and houses the fuel cell.
This Mustang has a great look and sounds extremely tough. Whoever ends up with it is going to have so much fun tearing up the streets! Make it yours for $25,500.00!

This 1966 Ford Mustang is a throwback to the glory days of Muscle Cars from the 1960's. This isn't your average "grocery getter" pony..!!! This car is all about the look and feel of the original Mustangs and all the POWER you can feel down to your bones when you drive it! If you are looking for a car that is, in every sense of the term... a Hot Rod then this is the car you've been looking for! That being said, great effort has also been made to make sure it's not only fun to drive, but reliable too.

AND... not only does she sound good from the outside (and it does!), but with an all new sound system including a new Retro bluetooth AM/FM/USB/SIRIUS ready radio, power-rated wiring, a 180watt AMP for the quad Pioneer speakers, and a 300watt Subwoofer.
Below is a list of all the maintenance, restorations and upgrades recently completed:

Tuneup: - Adjusted carburetor settings - Set timing (was way too far advanced causing it to run hot) - Re-ran engine wiring (it was a tangled mess!) Rebuilt the alternator: - New brushes - Cleaned arbor contacts - Re-soldered loose (cold soldered) coil wire
Misc: - Cleaned and lubed rear quarter window assemblies - Cleaned, painted and lubed front seat slider assemblies - Painted wheel wells black - Adjusted Emergency Brake cables (now it'll hold)

Replaced / Installed NEW: - Air Breather and filter - Battery cables - Starter solenoid - Radiator fan (FlexFan w/new aluminum spacer) - Thermostat - Chrome water-neck - Radiator hoses and clamps - Fuel Pump - In-line fuel filters - Carburetor "clear filter" screen - Fuel line hoses - Rear quarter panel "brake vent" ornaments - Rocker panel plates (under doors on both sides - New chrome lug nuts on all wheels - Gas cap gasket - Tail light bulbs (new LED bills) - Tail light assembly gaskets and mounting screws - Trunk "left fender" floor panel - Shifter rebuild kit (stopped shifter rattling) - Rear-view mirror - Rubber visor post-ends - Cigarette Lighter - New cigarette lighter socket - Trim screws throughout the interior - Painted windshield side posts - Instrument panel light sockets - Instrument panel light bulbs (new LED bulbs) - Steering column mounted tachometer - Wired to light with instrument panel lights - All seat belts (with proper retro clasps) - Entire sound system - New high-amp wiring kit for radio and subwoofer - New "Retro" stereo with: - Bluetooth (including mic for hands free phone calls) - 2 USB inputs - 2 Aux audio jack inputs - Sirius ready (needs Sirius module) - RCA front, rear and subwoofer outputs - Antenna assembly (front fender) - Amp for front and read speakers mounted in the trunk - New divider/mounting board behind rear seat in the trunk - 6x9 Pioneer speakers in rear deck - Retro-styled rear deck speaker covers - New read deck panel - 6.5" Pioneer speakers in front kick panels - New kick panels molded for speakers - 8" Powered subwoofer box in the trunk - Installed socket plug for easy removal/install of subwoofer box - New Dynamat sound dampening matting throughout cab - Scraped, painted and sealed holes in floorboards
